title: fixed index out of range on bad files
body:
Not sure if this is the 'proper' fix or not, however, I was using csvkit to grok a ugly CSV file from a client and was constantly getting a index out of range when running:

csvgrep -m "inspiring ideas to discover." -c 4 EK_ContentTableDump.csv

It failed in my case with a 'index out of range'.  I added a try/catch around it and it seems to work (properly) now.

title: Option to remove duplicate columns on full outer join
csvclean must must respect delimiter in output file
body:
Hi,

The output file of "csvclean" use ',' (comma)  as delimiter even if the delimiter option (-d) has been specified. 

Maybe it's better that the output have the same delimiter than the input.

Regards

title: csvstat doen't give counts for some columns
body:
csvstat is great, and usually gives a sense of the mode of the data, via a count of how many rows have the most frequent values: 
 4. LAST_NAME
        
        Nulls: True
        Unique values: 307123
        5 most frequent values:
                SMITH:  28155
                JOHNSON:        23713
                MARTINEZ:       18465
                MILLER: 16916
                BROWN:  15428
        Max length: 28
But sometimes it doesn't, perhaps when there less than some predefined number of unique values: 
28. STATUS
        
        Nulls: False
        Values: Active, Inactive
I'd like to get counts of the top 5 most frequent values for all columns, as long as there are any repeated values.

title: Help users fix `field larger than field limit (131072)` problem via `-u 3`
body:
Files with unbalanced single or double quotes can lead to the puzzling error `FieldSizeLimitError: CSV contains fields longer than maximum length of 131072 characters. Try raising the maximum with the --maxfieldsize flag.`

It took me a long time to figure out that it was actually a quoting problem, partly because the files are enormous.

Please have the error message also recommend trying the `quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONE` dialect, aka `--quoting 3`

See e.g. [CSP's answer to _csv.Error: field larger than field limit (131072) - Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/18408911/507544) which suggests that it may actually be more common for people to encounter QUOTE_NONE problems than fields longer than 131072 bytes.

title: Streaming option for --no-inference?  Running out of memory
body:
Like issue #338, I'm trying to work with data that won't fit in memory (even my 16 GB).

I'm running `in2csv --no-inference` to convert file types, change delimiters etc.
Since I don't want data inference for this particular problem, it should be possible to stream the data.

If it would be too much to implement a streaming option here, I wonder if any can recommend another good tool out there for just properly changing delimiters and the like for big data files.

title: Fix #379 in2csv --no-inference use infer_types
body:
It looks like in2csv was just using the wrong kwarg.

Changed --no-inference to set infer_types like table.py does, not type_inference.

title: in2csv --no-inference fail: TypeError: 'type_inference' is an invalid keyword argument for this function
body:
It seems that in2csv is now just sending all its arguments as kwargs to csv.reader, which doesn't handle the 'type_inference' argument. 
$ in2csv -v --no-inference csvkit-testinference.csv > to-n.csv
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/in2csv", line 9, in 
    load_entry_point('csvkit==0.9.0', 'console_scripts', 'in2csv')()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/utilities/in2csv.py", line 82, in launch_new_instance
    utility.main()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/utilities/in2csv.py", line 76, in main
    data = convert.convert(self.input_file, filetype, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/convert/__init__.py", line 44, in convert
    return csv2csv(f, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/convert/csvitself.py", line 11, in csv2csv
    tab = table.Table.from_csv(f, **kwargs) 
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/table.py", line 210, in from_csv
    rows = CSVKitReader(f, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/csvkit/unicsv.py", line 44, in __init__
    self.reader = csv.reader(f, **kwargs)
TypeError: 'type_inference' is an invalid keyword argument for this function

title: Make sqlalchemy an optional dependency
body: We are using csvkit to work with CSV files and we believe we are not using any sqlalchemy-related functionality. If this library can provide significant functionality without it, could it be made an extra optional requirement?

title: Add --linestyle option to support unicode line-drawing characters in table output
body: Shamelessly copying psql's \pset linestyle unicode.

body:

Keep up the great work!

Thanks,
Bela


title: Can't refer to more columns after referring to a column that has a colon in it
body:
```bash
> csvcut -c '1,B11001002 - Family households:,10' household_type.csv 
Invalid range %s. Ranges must be two integers separated by a - or : character.
```
I have tried various ways of escaping the colon, but none seem to work.

title: csvgrep -r doesn't find matches across newlines
body:
I'm using csvkit 0.9.0.

Given the following CSV in `test.csv`:

```
user_id,body
gabebw,"IRC
AIM"
```

`csvgrep` can find the row when matching on `IRC`, which is on the first line:

```
$ csvgrep -c body -r IRC test.csv
user_id,body
gabebw,"IRC
AIM"
```

But when I try to match on `AIM`, which is on a newline but still part of the row, `csvgrep` does not find the row:

```
$ csvgrep -c body -r AIM test.csv
user_id,body
```

Am I using `-r` incorrectly, or maybe passing it the wrong input?

title: Error/warn when converting JSON with nested values
csvjoin should throw more explicit errors when column names don't match because of whitespace
body:
I was trying to perform a csvjoin, and I was getting the following output: 
*Column identifier "xxx" is neither an integer, nor a existing column's name.*
The thing was, that the field name contained a blank space before the name. Perhaps it could be helpful to trim all the blank spaces at the beginning and at the end of the column name.
What do you think? If you agree and give me some hints, I can do it :)

Thanks

title: in2csv doesn't handle blank fields?
body: The in2csv tutorial file (ne_1033_data.xlsx) contains blank values for the item_name for multiple rows.  Consequently, the processed file (data.csv) has shifted the values where they are not aligned to the column correctly in rows that contain blank values.   Is there a way to process a file with blank values within a column and align the columns correctly?

title: Add csvsplit utility
body:
This resolves issue onyxfish/csvkit#250, introducing a csvsplit utility that does the inverse operation of csvstack.

Includes tests, does not include documentation yet.

title: add csvdiff utility using daff library
body:
Adds a `csvdiff` command, similar to unix `diff` but for tabular data (see #12). Implemented as a simple wrapper around the [`daff`](https://github.com/paulfitz/daff) library. The diff is itself a csv, in [coopy format](http://dataprotocols.org/tabular-diff-format/), and has color highlighting when written to a terminal:
![csvdiff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/118367/4837381/f0e972e8-5fd4-11e4-8821-aada07e3ce45.png)
The utility seems to work across the range of python versions that `csvkit` is supported for.

title: text value loaded as a single char in csvsql
body:
I am trying to load a tsv file into mssql.
The numeric columns are loaded correctly, but all the textual columns are loaded as a single char.
I don't know if it is related, but the columns' type according to csvstat is "unicode".

Is the problem related to encoding? I found this [related post in stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17394092/only-first-character-of-unicode-strings-getting-written-to-csv) 
Is there a solution?

title: Add csvplot command line script
body:
This adds plotting functionality to csvkit. The plots can be seen in a browser or saved to .png and .xml.

If you want to see how it looks I built the docs [here](http://yasermartinez.com/csvplot/scripts/csvplot.html).

I decided to use pygal instead of matplotlib because it is a small library, the plots look better and has no dependencies. I considered Bokeh but it also has a hard dependency on numpy.

title: Cannot load international data into MySQL; delimiter confusion
body:
Great piece of software!

On the off-chance that the issue is with me and not CSVKit, I have opened a question on StackOverflow also:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26205666/how-to-load-international-data-into-mysql-using-csvkit

Has anyone seen the following issue?

I am loading a a pipe-delimited file of hotels into MySQL using CSVKit (https://csvkit.readthedocs.org/en/0.9.0/index.html).

Some of the hotel name fields contain "non-English" characters ( e.g. "nedin Hostel").  I have noticed that the character "" in particular tends to confuse "csvsql" regarding the pipe delimiter ("|"), causing both the record that contains the "non-English" character--and also the "next" record in the delimited file--to fail to load the fields correctly (both NULLs loaded and "fields offset" occur; the "" character is ommitted entirely).

The original fa
iled configuration was discovered using the following:

MySQL Schema Character Set:  "DEFAULT COLLATE utf8_general_ci"
csvsql Command: csvsql --blanks -d "|" -e "iso-8859-1" --db mysql://root:pwd@localhost:3306/schema_name --table table_name --insert CSVFileName.csv 

Okay, I now know that ""iso-8859-1"" is the same thing as "latin1_swedish_ci" in MySQL and that  _might_ explain the original failure...however, I cannot find the encoding parameter to pass to "csvsql" that will cause it to load "UTF-8".  I have tried every variant of "utf-8" that would seem appropriate, thus:

csvsql Command: csvsql --blanks -d "|" -e "UTF-8" --db mysql://root:pwd@localhost:3306/schema_name --table table_name --insert CSVFileName.csv 

--or--

csvsql Command: csvsql --blanks -d "|" -e "utf-8" --db mysql://root:pwd@localhost:3306/schema_name --table table_name --insert CSVFileName.csv 

--or--

csvsql Command: csvsql --blanks -d "|" -e "utf8" --db mysql://root:pwd@localhost:3306/schema_name --table table_name --insert CSVFileName.csv 

I have alos tried different MySQL Schema character sets, particularly:

*  "DEFAULT COLLATE utf8_general_ci"
*  "DEFAULT COLLATE utf8_unicode_ci"
*  "DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8mb4"
*  "DEFAULT COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci"  (see "https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4")

Attempting the last two configs generates an interesting error:  "OperationalError) (1118, 'Row size too large. The maximum row size for the used table type, not counting BLOBs, is 65535. You have to change some columns to TEXT or BLOBs')", from:

MySQL Schema Character Set:  "DEFAULT COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci"
csvsql Command: csvsql --blanks -d "|" -e "utf8" --db mysql://root:pwd@localhost:3306/schema_name --table table_name --insert CSVFileName.csv 


I suspec that the issue lies with the encoding parameter in "csvsql", but I could be wrong.  It might be combination of the encoding and the schema character set...

The question is:  What is that parameter? or what is the combination of the parameter with the character set for international data?

CSVKit uses SQLAclchemy (http://www.sqlalchemy.org/).  According to the SQLAlchemy docs you would expect the parameter to be "utf8" (http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/dialects/mysql.html), but as mentioned, that does not seem to work (see above).

One other bit of sleuthing:  According to the CSVKit docs "Python 3s csv module supports unicode internally".  My Ubuntu machine's default Python version is "Python 2.7.6".  I do, however, have the latest Python 3.x installed and up-to-date, so one would think that CSVKit would use that (if available), right?  If not, how would I I make CSVKit use Python 3?

Any ideas or suggested best-practices for loading international data would be appreciated.  (I am asking for guidance on the best set of default schema settings to use with MySqL for a varied set of international data.  In effect, what is the most "future proof" way to build all MySQL schemas?)

Thanks.

Shameless

title: csvsql and sqlite table name
body:
Hi,
if I run this command I have a token error (unrecognized token: "05_temp ..."):
csvsql --query  "select * from 05_temp group by numero_protocollo" 05_temp.csv

I have this error because csvsql create a temp sqlite table and sqlite tables name cannot start with a number.

Probably it would be better to have an error related to table name and not to a token. But I do not know it is simple.

Thank you

title: "skip lines" feature
body:
Sometimes the first few lines of a csv need to be skipped (header comments, copyright lines). It would be nice to have this capability in csvkit.
I think it belongs in the reader's constructor.

title: in2csv error
body:
Invoking in2csv results in an error:  'file' object has no attribute 'rfind'

On Mac OS X 10.9.4.  Ran an update to make sure I had all the correct pieces:

sh-3.2# pip install csvkit --upgrade
Requirement already up-to-date: csvkit in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages
Requirement already up-to-date: xlrd>=0.7.1 in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: sqlalchemy>=0.6.6 in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: openpyxl>=2.0.3 in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: six>=1.6.1 in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: python-dateutil==1.5 in /System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Extras/lib/python (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: dbf==0.94.003 in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from csvkit)
Requirement already up-to-date: jdcal in /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages (from openpyxl>=2.0.3->csvkit)
Cleaning up...

Thanks!
